content.description:
Layback the right edge of the fin shaped boulder near the base of the sport route

Yellow Brick Road

and top out.
content.location: Locate the sport route and you'll see a blocky fin shaped boulder.  Downclimb the chimney

climbs.name: Yellow Brick Road
climbs.fa: Tim Powers, Neal Strickland, Tracy Crabtree - 1992

content.description:
Climb through some 5.9 edgy slab terrain to a stopper crux. After committing to the fierce move relax for a moment on a good ledge. Then mantel (or dyno!) your way to easier ground and the anchors.

Beautiful stone and great moves make for a classic (though anti-sterotypical) RRG climb.
content.location: Hike along the wall to the right from the Diamond in the Rough area past a grungy section of cliff. You'll pass between the main cliff and a boulder, then you'll see an orange fin shaped boulder. This is the next sport line past the fin.

content.description:
Wolverine Boulder

Body english will get you up this steep offset prow. The moves are fun, but hard to unlock. There are established problems to the right on this boulder.
content.location:
From the route The Shining, walk (read:bushwhack) straight down the hill to a pyramid shaped boulder. Once you know where it is it's easy to find from the Global Village trail.

The problem follows the obvious steep prow in the middle of the downhill face.

Downclimb backside of boulder

content.description:
On the Witch's Castle.

Immediately to the right of

Green Piece

climb up nice edges to a crimp sidepull and top out.
content.location: Second line right of the left end of the west face of the main Witch's Castle boulder

content.description:
Climb easy, but off balance moves to a distinct crux where the angle changes from vertical to low angle. The climbing is much easier after the crux.

One first time climber, having trouble with the crux moves was reported to have called out, "These nerds are hard to hang on to!"

Check out the cool iron oxide features.
content.protection: Four bolts and rappel anchors on the ledge. SLing long for top roping and make sure to rappel to get down.
content.location: Directly under the upper pitch of Whiteout.

content.description:
Climb the original flake and ramp system to the left for full trad experience of climb an alternate start which has been bolted and is in a plumbline with the rap anchors on the first belay.

Once you reach the exposed and comfortable ledge continue up the dihedral. You need to exit the crack onto the left face when it becomes possible (about 15 feet above where the crack jogs hard right at a horizontal). Climb up big ledges to the bolt anchors. Rappel twice to get down.

This route is mostly face climbing near a crack and is a whole heck of a lot of fun!
content.protection: Standard rock, you don't need much smaller gear, mostly tight hands to fist sized.
content.location: From the road you can spot this line as you head north on hwy 11 back toward Slade. It is the first crack right of the obvious and striking arete. To reach it from the wall, hike left from the Diamond in the Rough area through a talus covered ledge. When the trail drops down and the rock is grey again look up and spot a short sport route with an obvious dihedral above. Begin on a ledge.

content.description:
This problem ascends the southwest corner of the Welcome Boulder. Start from a sit down start using the hidden undercling and make your way up. End with a surprise and bask in your glory!

Down climb on the north side of the boulder. Be careful it's quite mossy.

This climb is more for the type of person who wants to climb everything regardless of how dirty/short it is.
content.location: Take the trail up to the split between the trail that goes left to Emerald City and the right trail to Global Village. Look left and this boulder will will be next to the trail to Emerald City. It's the obvious dirty boulder.

content.description:
Wolverine Boulder

Climb the less than vertical face to the right of the prow and top out.
content.location:
From

Wolverine

take a step right.

content.description:
This problem ascends the southeast dirty crack on this boulder. Begin with a cool chickenhead, and make your way up and through a a good portion of moss to the top of the boulder.

Down climb on the north side of the boulder. Be  careful it's quite mossy.

This climb is more for the type of person who wants to climb everything regardless of how dirty/short it is.
content.location: Take the trail up to the split between the trail that goes left to Emerald City and the right trail to Global Village. Look left and this boulder will will be next to the trail to Emerald City. It's the obvious dirty boulder.

content.description: Climb the dihedral by stemming and locking to a ledge with a large loose block and rappel. The route can be continued to the top through the dirty crack system.
content.protection: Standard RRG rack up to BD C4 #3.
content.location: Located in a dihedral 50 feet right of The Bulge.

content.description:
Slab problem left of

Knobs, Etc.
content.location: Descend to the base of the Knobs Boulder and climb the face left of the easier line on the arete.

content.description:
Wookie Boulder

R to L traverse.  This is an extension of

Let the Wookie Win.

Went back later and added a few more moves. Begin as far right as feasible and traverse into and finish on

Let the Wookie Win.

Step off in the trail.
content.location: South face (downhill side) of the Wookie Boulder.

content.description:
Climb pockets and stem off edges on the north side of the main Witch's Castle boulder.  Downclimb

Green Piece.
content.location: Center of the concave section of the north (uphill) face of the boulder

content.description:
A fun, albeit dirty hand crack that climbs through a few small rhodos to nice ledge topout, making liberal use of face holds when the crack tightens up. The FA started from a dirty hueco below the ledge that ruby slippers and flying monkeys start from, but you can also skip the lower start and traverse to a hueco and begin there.

As of Oct. 2020 there's a solid anchor/rap tree on the right once you reach the ledge. Bring some cord for the belay. No need to leave tat for the rap, the rope should pull just fine.
content.location: the crack just left of the ledge that flying monkeys and ruby slippers starts from

content.description:
On the Witch's Castle

Thin slab in the middle of the west face.  Climb straight up through a round iron oxide feature.
content.location: Center of the west face

content.description:
Shelf Life Boulder

Start on the same hold as

Shelf Life

, but go up and slightly right to top out.
content.location: Center of the uphill face.  Downclimb to the right.

content.description:
Solitaire Boulder

Sit start, climb the blunt arete, laying off slopers, and top out on the horseback arete.
content.location: Left end of the boulder between the trad route Scarecrow and Black Magic Boulder.  Downclimb chimney in the back

content.description:
Skittles Boulder

Start low on the right-hand side of the face and do the rising traverse along the slopey lip. Either continue down the other side or top out at the apex of the face.
content.location: This problem can be described as either the north face of the boulder directly downhill from the route Scarecrow or the north face of the boulder immediately west and slightly downhill of the Black Magic Arete boulder. Scramble off the back.

content.description: Boulder out the tough opening moves with a good spot or tricky gear. Once you get established at a rest the route is pretty straightforward. Plug up some good fingerlocks on an aesthetic splitter crack in beautiful, solid stone. It needs to be much longer, but alas!
content.protection:
Nuts and TCUs work well, with a couple smaller cams (#.75 and #1 camalot size).

Bolted anchors
content.location: From Yellow Brick road walk a few yards to the right. You can't miss this striking short route.

content.description:
Shelf Life Boulder

Begin on a chevron shaped hold left of center, deadpoint to the slopey shelf to the left, mantel up, and top out.

Downclimb to the right
content.location:
From Let the Wookie Win cross the trail and hike up the hill toward the main wall. If you find the pointed Wolverine Boulder hike right (east) past a friable boulder to a more solid rock with a distinct flat ledge on the uphill (north) face.

This is directly below but a little ways down the hill from the sport route The Bulge.

content.description:
The crack itself is fairly easy and secure. When the crack turns a ledge step left and pull onto a slab. Protect out of the thin crack and practice your slab technique.

I love this route, but some people think it's stupid. It's really a matter of taste I guess.
content.protection: The initial crack take progressively smaller gear from #4 to #1 camalot sizes. The upper slab takes small cams and offset nuts. The second half of this route protects like a dream with passive gear. Bolted anchors with rap rings
content.location:
Walk around the corner left from the start of Whiteout and find the splitter crack near the corner.

Best bet is to rappel from a single bolt on No Place Like Home. This route really needs its own anchors.

content.description: Sit start on right side of Dangboy Boulder on a deep pocket and jug. Move up to a good edge, then bump over to the big pocket. Move up on pockets to a great ledge and top out in a tricky position.
content.location: Right side of the face of Dang Boy Boulder, which is the big, clean-faced boulder about 20 feet from the left side of the Global Village trail. A large fallen tree rests along the face.

content.description:
Another great climb on Emerald City.  A great circuit for this area is to access the ledge and do all 5 adjacent climbs without untying your shoes or rope.

Just right of the obvious scoop at the bottom of Flying Monkeys lies another bolted line. Climb up the edge of the "dish" and head for anchors at the top. There may be no particular crux on this climb, but it is not without some hard moves. The holds are small, but mostly good. Wear your edging shoes!
content.location:
The approach trail to Emerald City leads up below a large ledge,perhaps 10 meters up that lies below a flat, vertical, brown and tan striped wall. Access the ledge via scrambling to the left and arrive at the base of 5 sport climbs, from left to right being:

Flying Monkeys, Ruby Slippers, Diamond In the Rough, Oz, and Lollipop Kids.

content.description:
Ripple Boulder

Climb the center of the downhill face on cool sandstone ripples.  Walk off back.
content.location:
Hike uphill from Shelf Life Boulder, or downhill from the cliff near the sport route

The Bulge.

This small boulder is near the base of the cliff, but is a little down the hill.

content.description: A thin crimpy face climb up the left side of the wall.
content.location: The second to last bolted route on the Emerald City wall, just right of Diamond In The Rough.

content.description:
One of the finest sport routes in all of the Red, and for that matter, anywhere. That is the reason for my choice for it to be the first one I went back for upon 'homecoming' in Y2K. The name is a great coincidence.

Climb an easy face past a few bolts and move out left onto a steep arete in the sun. Climb past perhaps 10 bolts to the anchors on smaller holds than are common in the red, using the arete frequently for hands and heels.
content.location: At the far left end of Emerald City, this steep and tall arete beckons- climb it! This is the last bolted route to the left on this crag.

content.description:
On the Witch's Castle (Boulder)

Climb right of center of the west face on the best and most obvious line up some nice rounded iron oxide edges. This is the first reasonable line left of the top of the Knobs Boulder.

Downclimb

Green Piece

on the left end of the same face.
content.location: Where the approach trail for Global Village splits off, take the right (Global) fork. Immediately look for a cluster of boulders to the south and downhill from the trail. On the west face of the boulder closest to the parking area begin just left of the top of a smaller boulder which continues down the hill (there is an easier "pitch" below). Downclimb near the NW corner of the boulder.

content.description:
Sound & Fury Boulder

In the center of the downhill face begin on two deep pockets.  Undercling and lay off to the left, throw for a good hold, and top out.

Walk off back
content.location: Center of the south face

content.description: Climb the vertical face to a committing move from the slabby face on the right onto the arete. Easier ground takes you to the ledge.
content.protection: Top rope from Whiteout first belay anchors with a long piece of rope using a small tree for a directional.
content.location: This is the arete to the right of Whiteout Direct. Start directly under the arete, move slightly right onto the slab and then back left onto the arete.

content.description:
Start off the ledge into the right-leaning finger crack. Smear, lock and press your way through the entirety of the route.

If accessing via rappel, the gear anchor at the bottom of the crack takes hand-sized gear (recommended); however, there is also a bolted anchor 10ft below on a very sandy ledge.
content.protection: Finger-sized cams, heavy on 0.4 BD Camalots. Rap rings at the top.
content.location: This climbs the acute dihedral off a sandy ledge 40 ft up the wall just around the corner from Whiteout. Rappel in from the right tree ledge finish on Whiteout or, alternatively, climb through sand and choss to gain the ledge from the ground.

content.description:
Generator Boulder

Start same as

Generator

but go left
content.location: On the west face.  Walk off/downclimb left

content.description:
The right-most bolted line on the ledge above the approach trail. Start up past a few bolts and a few hard moves on pockets to reach good edges (better holds) on a slabby face. Head up to the anchors past 4 more clips.

But was it Lollipop Kids or Lollipop Guild? Me thinks the latter in the Wizard Of Oz.
content.location:
The approach trail to Emerald City leads up below a large ledge,perhaps 10 meters up that lies below a flat, vertical, brown and tan striped wall. Access the ledge via scrambling to the left and arrive at the base of 5 sport climbs, from left to right being:

Flying Monkeys, Ruby Slippers, Diamond In the Rough, Oz, and Lollipop Kids.

content.description:
Wookie Boulder

On the west face of the boulder begin low and to the right and traverse left all the way back to the trail utilizing flat ledges and thin feet.  This was the original problem on the boulder.

Beware of the flat rock behind you in the middle of the traverse.
content.location: Hike along the trail toward Global Village. After passing through a gully under a boulder and then a huge moss covered slabby boulder look for a vegetated boulder on the right side of the trail with a line of ledges along its west face.

content.description: Climb a low angle arete and top out.
content.location: Drop down to the base of the smaller boulder on the SW corner of the main Witch's Castle boulder.  Right side of the slabby face.

content.description:
Climb the north face of this boulder. Start on crimps and double digit crimps. Move to limited options, and pull up on top.

Downclimb (read jump) onto a crashpad, where the boulder creates a corridor at the corridor's west end. It's the shortest there, and there's a good jug and foot about halfway down the face.
content.location:
Take the tail headed to Emerald City and continue along the trail until the trail opens up and

Yellow Brick Road

will be right in front of you. This route is located on the boulder to the left (west) of the massive orange boulder, to the left (west) of

Yellow Brick Road

. This problem is on the northeast arete of the boulder.

content.description:
On the east face of the Monkey's Lair.

Sit start under a hollow flake feature on small edges. Crank up on a series of better edges taking you up and slightly right to the apex of the overhanging face.
content.location: From My Sexy Cranberry walk around to the east side of the boulder, through a passage between the Cranberry boulder and the next boulder with an overhanging prow on its downhill side. Walk under the prow and turn left to the east face of the boulder. Look for some good edges down low and follow more of the same up the face to a good top out. The first big hold is a hollow flake. Fun moves!

content.description:
On the Witch's Castle (Boulder)

This is the boulder downclimb.  Climb the left end of the west face of the main boulder using a nice flake feature.
content.location: Right side of the NW corner of the Witch's Castle

content.description:
Shelf Life Boulder

Just right of center on the uphill face climb the small arete feature on slopey holds and small feet.

Downclimb to the right.
content.location: Distinct angling arete feature on uphill face.

content.description:
On the Wolverine Boulder

Layback off the arete between

Tusken Raider

and

Beast.
content.protection: Crash pad.  Take care with low boulder behind you
content.location: On the right edge of the downhill face of the Wolverine Boulder.

content.description: Not technically hard, but definitely heady as described.  Begin in the low dihedral at the left edge of the Yellow Brick Toad boulder.  Layback off the front edge of the fin boulder with your feet on the slab boulder to the left.  Don't use the back edge of the fin.  Top out on the fin.
content.location:
Left edge of the fin boulder near the start of

Yellow Brick Road.

content.description:
Generator Boulder

Sit start left of the southwest corner on crimps and climb up the edge of a circular feature to the top.
content.location: Between the Wolverine Boulder and the Shelf Life Boulder.  Left of the SW corner.  Walk of/downclimb left

content.description:
A short hard crux on smaller holds leads to easier climbing on the face above.

Start off the ledge by stepping into a bowl-shaped depression in the wall and start climbing in earnest. Clip a bolt and crimp up over the lip of this bowl and boulder through the crux. Clip another bolt and climb easier face  moves to the top with a good anchor.
content.location:
The approach trail to Emerald City leads up below a large ledge,perhaps 10 meters up that lies below a flat, vertical, brown and tan striped wall. Access the ledge via scrambling to the left and arrive at the base of 5 sport climbs, from left to right being:

Flying Monkeys, Ruby Slippers, Diamond In the Rough, Oz, and Lollipop Kids.

content.description:
Fictitious Egg Boulder

Weird sit/contort start in the scoop on the corner of the boulder utilizing thin edges for your hands. Pop up to a sloper edge, match, mantel and slab to the top.
content.location: On the Global Village trail on the SW corner of the large mossy slab boulder after the first gully crossing you'll spy a scoop (the inside of the egg) near the ground with a small rail above it a few feet below a rounded ledge. Walk off left.

content.description:
Pitch 1 (5.3): Climb the nice looking, but extremely sand crack in a dihedral to a ledge. Move left from the rockhouse and bushwhack vertically to a ledge below the second pitch.

Pitch 2 (5.5): Climb the face next to the right arching crack to a committing top out.
content.protection: First pitch is mostly hand sized gear. Second pitch is small and medium sized cams.
content.location: From Whiteout, walk left around the corner to a left facing dihedral. Rappel the route. It has been reported that you can walk off from the belay ledge, but I do not have first hand knowledge of this descent.

content.description:
Generator Boulder

Climb the southwest corner of the boulder.
content.location: SW corner of boulder.  Walk off/downclimb left

content.description: An excellent sport route up thin, crimpy holds.
content.protection: 7 bolts in 80' to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Located in Emerald City.  Diamond in the Rough is the second bolted route right of the large hueco, just left of Oz.

content.description: Start matched on small angled jug, move left on decent edges to a big pocket. Big move to the sloper on the corner, then move up for the top out. Resist the temptation to use the mossy slab around the corner for feet; stay on the front face only.
content.protection: Pad, spotter. Be careful of the tree branch waiting to impale you during the top out.
content.location: Left side of Dang Boy Boulder, which is the big, clean-faced boulder about 20 feet from the left side of the Global Village trail. A large fallen tree rests along the face, and the roots stick up right near the top-out to this problem.

content.description:
Sit start and climb the steep arete left of

Green Piece.
content.location: NW corner of the main Witch's Castle boulder.

content.description:
Solitaire Boulder

Utilize the iron oxide "eyebrow" and the blunt arete to ascend this boulder to the summit.  Downclimb chimney in the back
content.location: From the route Scarecrow as you face the cliffline this will be the obvious pointed boulder to the right, just before you go through the passageway to Yellow Brick Road. Look for the obvious slot/pocket to begin. Chimney down the backside.

content.description: Early and fun crux but not fun enough to make the rest of the route worth it.  Look out at the chossy bulge.

On the block that creates a passage located between Scarecrow and Yellow Brick Road is this heady (for the grade) face and arete problem. Climb the right side of the northeast arete (the one closest to YBR) to a good top out.

The landing is bad and the moves are sort of commiting as you fight the barndoor effect.
content.protection: A pad for certain, maybe two and a good spot.
content.location: NE corner of the boulder at the base of the wall between the routes Scarecrow and Yellow Brick Road. This is not the freestanding flake/boulder, this boulder is a few yards west of that one.

content.description:
Same start as

Fall Guy

and traverse right and top out
content.location: Begin SW corner.  Walk off/downclimb left

content.description:
Climb the northeast arete of the tall boulder. Start on edges, move to the arete, move up and pull over the top of the boulder. Very cool problem.

Downclimb (read jump) onto a crashpad, where the boulder creates a corridor at the corridor's west end. It's the shortest there, and there's a good jug and foot about halfway down the face.
content.protection: Crashpad. Maybe a spotter, there's a drop off at the base of the problem.
content.location:
Take the tail headed to Emerald City and continue along the trail until the trail opens up and

Yellow Brick Road

will be right in front of you. This route is located on the boulder to the left (west) of the massive orange boulder, to the left (west) of

Yellow Brick Road

. This problem is on the northeast arete of the boulder.

content.description:
Sound & Fury Boulder

Climb the obvious obtuse arete on the left side.

Walk off back
content.location: Hike past the Wookie Boulder toward Global Village.  When the trail gets out of the rocky section drop down below the trail to a lower bench.  Sound & Fury Boulder is the large, obvious boulder on your right overlooking the creek.  This problem is the southeast corner.

content.description: On the east face of the Wolverine boulder is a one move wonder. Grab the overhanging slopey flake and do a tenuous semi-sit start. Throw for the positive lip above and mantel out the finish. This is just a single low-percentage move.
content.protection: Maybe a spot to keep your noggin off the boulder behind you.
content.location: Step around the corner to the right of Wolverine and find a steep, short overhanging flake.
